verses.text: 葡萄園工人的比喻「天國好像一個家主，清早出去雇請工人到他的葡萄園工作。

words.note: Lit. 'grape garden'
Lit. 'compare and metaphor'
A central concept in Jesus' teachings
Lit. 'grape garden'

verses.text: 他和工人講定了一天的工錢是一個銀幣，然後派他們到葡萄園去。

words.note: Specifically refers to payment for labor
A common currency in biblical times
Lit. 'grape garden'

verses.text: 大約九點鐘，他又出去，看見還有人閒站在街市上，

words.note: Commonly used in biblical contexts for public squares.

verses.text: 就對他們說：『你們也到葡萄園來吧，我會給你們合理的工錢。』

words.note: Lit. 'grape garden'
Indicates suggestion or request.
Specifically refers to payment for labor

verses.text: 他們就去了。約在正午和下午三點鐘，他又出去，也是這樣作。
下午五點鐘左右，他再出去，看見還有人站著，就問他們：『你們為甚麼整天站在這裡不去作工？』

words.note: More common in biblical texts, modern Chinese often uses '工作' (gōngzuò).

verses.text: 他們回答：『沒有人用我們。』他說：『你們也到葡萄園來吧。』

words.note: Common in parables; refers to a field of grapevines.

verses.text: 到了黃昏，園主對管工說：『把工人叫來，給他們工錢，從最後的開始，到最先來的。』

words.note: Specifically refers to the owner of an orchard or vineyard, common in parables.

verses.text: 那些下午五點鐘才開始作工的人來了，每個人都領到一個銀幣。

words.note: More common in biblical texts, modern Chinese often uses '工作' (gōngzuò).
Often refers to the Roman denarius in biblical contexts, a day's wage for a laborer.

verses.text: 最先作工的人也來了，以為會多得一點，但每個人也是領到一個銀幣。

words.note: More common in biblical texts, modern Chinese often uses '工作' (gōngzuò).
Often refers to the Roman denarius in biblical contexts, a day's wage for a laborer.

verses.text: 他們領到之後，就埋怨家主，說：

words.note: Often used in biblical contexts for complaining against authorities or God.
Common term in parables, refers to the head of a household or estate.

verses.text: 『我們整天在烈日之下勞苦，這些後來的人只工作了一個小時，你卻給他們跟我們一樣的工錢。』

words.note: Often used to describe harsh conditions, as in the Bible.
Biblical term for strenuous, often suffering, work.

verses.text: 家主回答他們當中的一個，說：『朋友，我並沒有虧待你。你我不是講定了一個銀幣嗎？

words.note: Common term in parables, refers to the head of a household or estate.
Used to strengthen a negative statement.
To treat someone in a way that causes them loss or disadvantage.
Forms a rhetorical question expecting affirmation.
A denarius was a common Roman silver coin, a day's wage in the biblical context.

verses.text: 拿你的工錢走吧！我給那後來的和給你的一樣，是我的主意。

words.note: Refers to the master's own intention or decision.

verses.text: 難道我不可以照自己的主意用我的財物嗎？還是因為我仁慈你就嫉妒呢？』

words.note: Used to express incredulity or to emphasize a rhetorical question.
Refers to the master's own intention or decision.
A virtue often attributed to God in scripture.
A vice often warned against in the Bible.

verses.text: 因此，在後的將要在前，在前的將要在後。」

words.note: Lit. 'by this reason'
Indicates future tense
Indicates future tense

verses.text: 第三次預言受難及復活耶穌上耶路撒冷去的時候，把十二門徒帶到一邊，對他們說：

words.note: Refers to Christ's suffering
Lit. 'return to life'
Marks the 'ba' construction

verses.text: 「我們現在上耶路撒冷去，人子要被交給祭司長和經學家，他們要定他死罪，

words.note: A title for Jesus in the Gospels
Indicates future tense or intention
Compound for 'head priest'
Refers to legal experts or scribes in Judaism
Indicates future tense or intention
Lit. 'death crime'

verses.text: 把他交給外族人凌辱、鞭打，並且釘在十字架上。然而第三天他要復活。」

words.note: Marks the 'ba' construction
Refers to non-Jewish people
Lit. 'cross-shaped frame'
Directional complement or suffix
Indicates future tense or intention
Lit. 'return to life'

verses.text: 不是要人服事而是要服事人那時，西庇太的兒子的母親，帶著她的兩個兒子前來見耶穌。她跪在耶穌面前求他。

words.note: Can mean 'to serve' or 'service'
Can mean 'to serve' or 'service'

verses.text: 耶穌問她：「你想要甚麼？」她說：「求你下令，使我這兩個兒子在你的國裡，一個坐在你的右邊，一個坐在你的左邊。」
耶穌回答：「你們不知道你們求的是甚麼。我將要喝的杯，你們能喝嗎？」他們說：「能。」
他對他們說：「我的杯你們固然要喝，只是坐在我的左右，不是我可以賜的；我父預備賜給誰，就賜給誰。」
其他十個門徒聽見了，就向他們兄弟二人生氣。

words.note: Lit. 'door follower', implying entry into a school/teaching.

verses.text: 耶穌把他們叫過來，說：「你們知道各國都有元首統治他們，也有官長管轄他們。

words.note: Indicates direct object placed before verb.
Refers to ancient/religious officials, less common in modern secular contexts.

verses.text: 但你們中間卻不要這樣；誰想在你們中間成為大的，就要作你們的僕役；

words.note: Refers to a lowly servant or bondslave.

verses.text: 誰想在你們中間為首的，就要作你們的奴僕。

words.note: To be at the head; to lead.
Stronger term than 僕役, emphasizing ownership/bondage.

verses.text: 正如人子來，不是要受人的服事，而是要服事人，並且要捨命，作許多人的贖價。」

words.note: A title Jesus used for himself, emphasizing humanity and messianic role.

verses.text: 治好瞎眼的人他們從耶利哥出來的時候，有許多人跟著耶穌。

words.note: Lit. 'blind eyes'.

verses.text: 有兩個瞎眼的人坐在路旁，聽說耶穌經過，就喊叫：「主啊，大衛的子孫，可憐我們吧！」

words.note: Lit. 'blind eyes'.
Used as a respectful address for Jesus.
Refers to a lineage or posterity.

verses.text: 群眾責備他們，叫他們不要出聲，他們卻更加放聲喊叫：「主啊，大衛的子孫，可憐我們吧！」

words.note: 主 is a title for God or Christ; 啊 is an exclamatory particle.
Lit. 'son and grandson', referring to progeny.
Indicates suggestion or mild command.

verses.text: 耶穌就站住，叫他們過來，說：「要我為你們作甚麼呢？」

words.note: Often used to soften a question or ask for a suggestion.

verses.text: 他們說：「主啊，求你開我們的眼睛。」

words.note: 主 is a title for God or Christ; 啊 is an exclamatory particle.

verses.text: 耶穌就憐憫他們，摸他們的眼睛。他們立刻能看見，就跟從了耶穌。

words.note: Often used in a religious or formal context for deep compassion.
Often used in a discipleship context in the Bible.
Indicates completion or change of state.
